title: NT Government extends art grants to enrich its art tourism industry - Travelandtourworld.comTravelandtourworld.com
text:
NT Government extends art grants to enrich its art tourism industry Published on : Thursday, October 8, 2015
The next round of NT Government arts grants are now open with up to $15,000 available for individual projects.
The NT Arts Grants Program provides funding to develop and showcase the artistic talent of the Territory and enrich the lifestyle of Territorians through arts and cultural activities.
Arts and Museums Minister Gary Higgins urged local individuals, groups and non-profit organisations to apply for the grants.
“This round is for projects starting after 1 March next year,” Minister Higgins said.
“It’s funding which can help Territory artists to research and create new art works, develop artistic skills and professional networks, or tour and present their work in remote areas of the NT or other places in Australia.
“It is just another way the Northern Territory Government is supporting the arts and we will continue to support arts events and individual artists through programs and funding aimed at growing their work and their industry.”
Up to $15,000 is available for eligible projects. There is also a special category for emerging artists providing up to $10,000 for artists within the first five years of their professional practice.
The 2015 Project Round 1 provided $150 000 in funding to 13 arts projects, commencing from 1 July 2015.
Funding highlights included:
$2,800 for Breaking the Silence 2015 a workshop hosted by BreakdanceNT and Headspace Darwin which aimed to reduce Northern Territory’s suicide rates through offering dance workshops as a medium to promote the importance of positive mental health to young people, 12-25 years old.
$11,500 for the Satu Bulan Theatre Company (Indonesia) to facilitate a professional development opportunity for NT director / dramaturge Alex Galeazzi and playwright Sandra Thibodeaux led by Indonesian director Iswadi Pratama. The three artists will collaborate on a new cross-border work, The Age of Bones.
$15,000 to assist musician Shellie Morris; 2014 NT Australian of the Year and 2014/15 NAIDOC Artist of the Year in delivering a new recording enabling new national and international touring opportunities.
